solution.text:
\(QT_1\) and \(QT_2\) are tangents on the circle
this implies \(QT_1 \perp OT_1\) and \(QT_2 \perp OT_2\)
So, \(QT_1O\) and \(QT_2O\) are right angle triangles
Using Pythagoras on triangle \(QT_1O\) we have
we have \(QT_1\)=\(\sqrt {QO^2-OT_1^2}\)
we have \(QT_1\)=\(\sqrt {_{{j*5}}_^2-_{{j*3}}_^2}\)
\(\Rightarrow QT_1\)=\(\sqrt {_{j}_^2(5^2-3^2)}\)
\(\Rightarrow QT_1=_{{4*j}}_\)
Using Pythagoras on triangle \(QT_2O\) we have
we have \(QT_2\)=\(\sqrt {QO^2-OT_2^2}\)
we see that as \(OT_2\)=\(OT_1\)=radius of the circle
\(\Rightarrow QT_2=QT_1\)
\(QT_1+QT_2\)= 2\(\times QT_1\)= _{{2*j*4}}_cm
\(\angle OQT_1 = \angle OQT_2\) because \(\triangle QT_1O \cong \triangle QT_2O\)

content.text:
From an external point Q two tangents are drawn on the circle of radius _{{3*j}}_cm.
length of line joining Q with the centre of the circle, OQ=_{{5*j}}_cm
The two tangents touch the circle at points \(T_1\) and \(T_2\)
Choose the correct options

incorrect.text: \(\angle OQT_1\) is not equal to  \(\angle OQT_2\)

correct.text: The sum of lengths of the tangents, \(QT_1+QT_2\)= _{{2*j*4}}_cm
